I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  2011  country  programming  mission  for  technical  assistance  (TA),  the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) to deepen the capacity of county rural financial institutions to use and report on statistics 
for rural credit. A TA consultation mission from 13–15 February 2012 in Hainan Province, the 
PRC  and  subsequent  consultations  reviewed  the  field  circumstances,  and  discussed  and 
agreed  on the  objectives,  scope,  implementation  arrangements,  costs,  consultant terms of 
reference, and counterpart contributions for the proposed TA project.  
 
2.  The TA will enable small rural finance institutions to establish methods for effective 
computerization of new rural credit data requirements. It will include activities to ensure better 
comprehension  of  the  data  required,  and  their  use  by  managers,  statisticians,  and  local 
regulators  to  better  manage  risk  and  improve  financial  products.  The  TA  involves  an 
assessment  of  the  current  small  rural  financial  institution  account  and  loan  data  systems, 
methods of incorporating data extraction and submission in timely and cost-effective ways to 
provide reporting to regulators and to managers, options for programming, training in data 
collection, submission and use by managers of financial institutions, and dissemination of the 
results. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Evidence suggests that rural credit markets are imperfect, and efforts to improve market 
data can enhance competitiveness.2 Research in countries such as Brazil, India, and the United 
States demonstrates the importance and value of data on rural finance—in particular from a 
wider variety of types of financial institutions. Access to timely and reasonable quality data can 
improve institutional delivery of credit, provide a better understanding of market development to 
players and regulators, and improve public policy. Given the nature of risks in agriculture and 
rural livelihoods, data on the credit activities of smaller financial institutions can help policy 
makers stimulate growth in rural areas.  
 
4.  Rebalancing of economic welfare in the PRC is a central interest of the government, and 
rural household incomes and services have been the government’s key concern. In the financial 
sector deepening of rural financial system reform is under way, along with strengthening of 
financial  services  in  county  locations.  To  enable  tracking  of  financial  services  to  rural 
households, timely and high-quality rural financial statistics are essential. Existing data systems 
are a bottleneck, slowing the advance of rural financial reform and innovation. Although the 
Ministry of Finance and the People’s Bank of China (PBC), along with the China Banking 
Regulatory Commission, have promulgated policies to increase rural credit investment and 
related market development, the quality and timeliness of statistical reporting of rural financial 
institutions remains an urgent problem for the government.   
 
5.  Rural financial institutions in the PRC, especially small and medium-sized institutions, 
lack advanced and mature financial statistical monitoring and management systems as well as 
referential experience. Although the head office and provincial branches of the PBC have done 
substantial work to reinforce the statistics capacity of rural financial institutions, challenges exist

2   
regarding technique and practice references, particularly in computerization of data. The PBC 
wishes  to  advance  rural  financial  statistics  competence—improving  training,  information 
exchange, and statistics capacity establishment in financial institutions at the county level. 
Computerization and standardization of data and better understanding of what the data mean is 
an important aspect of this process. 
 
6.  Component 2 of ADB’s TA for Rural Finance Innovation and Rural and Agriculture 
Financial  Statistical  System  Development 3   supported  the  PBC  to  investigate  forms  of 
agricultural finance statistics in other countries, explore current methods of statistical collection 
and  analysis,  identify  issues,  and  establish  a  new  reporting  structure.  The  main  problem 
identified was weak rural credit data collection and submission systems, most of which is done 
manually using a variety of sources. The executing agency, the PBC Statistics Department, 
recognized that the capacity of rural financial institutions to identify trends and uses of rural 
credit data was limited. This led statisticians and managers in rural financial institutions to place 
less effort on the correct input and submission of data to the regulator, and indicated poor 
understanding of how the data can improve financial institution operations. 
  
7.  The  following  improvements  are  critical:  to  (i)  build  integrated  development  and 
evaluation systems for financial statistical abilities, to address significant regional differences in 
the capacity and responsiveness of rural financial institutions; (ii) establish an integral scheme 
or target-oriented method for improvement and computerization; (iii) enhance the reconstruction 
of  the  financial  statistical  monitoring  and  management  system  together  with  other  related 
systems in rural financial institutions; (iv) strengthen statistical system training among statistical 
staff  and  managers  in  rural  financial  institutions;  and  (v)  boost  information  exchange  and 
business communication between counties and provinces.  
 
8.  The first pillar of ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC, 2011–2015 is inclusive 
growth—a core value in the government’s 12th five-year plan.4  Improving access to finance and 
management of natural resources are the two main areas of support. The proposed TA directly 
supports  inclusive  growth  by  providing  better  information  on  the  financial  flows  to  rural 
households and businesses, thus enabling policy makers to understand and improve rules to 
increase financial access, particularly in rural areas. 
 
9.  The proposed TA builds on ADB’s TA for Rural Finance Innovation and Rural and 
Agriculture Financial Statistical System Development by establishing methods of integrating 
computerized data systems into existing accounts systems in small financial institutions in rural 
areas, and arranging for electronic submission and monitoring by local PBC offices.   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The expected impact is improved quality, completeness, and timeliness of rural credit 
statistics,  measured  by  computerized  rural  credit  statistics  system  submissions  to  the  PBC, 
targeted at 70% by the end of 2017 (baseline zero). The expected outcome is the computerization 
of rural credit statistics systems for small financial institutions in selected counties, with a target of 
40%  of  county  statistics  computerized  by  the  end  of  2015  (baseline  zero).  By  the  end  of 
                                                
3  ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Rural Finance Innovation and Rural and 
Agriculture Financial Statistical System Development. Manila.  
4  ADB. 2012. People’s Republic of China: Country Partnership Strategy. Manila.

3 
implementation of the TA, a clear template will be provided to all rural financial institutions with 
instructions  on  how  they  may  incorporate  it  into  their  existing  accounting  and  loan  data 
management systems on a computerized basis. In addition, rural financial institution managers 
and statisticians, and PBC county office staff, will have been trained, and their knowledge tested. 
In this way, stakeholders can understand how to use the rural financial statistics submissions for 
better  business  development  and  risk  management,  and  can  support  expansion  of  the 
computerized statistics systems and data submissions. The PBC will continue to evaluate the 
levels of computerized data submissions to monitor outcome progress. 
   
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will deliver four major outputs:   
 
(i)  a methodology for computerized submissions of rural credit statistics to the PBC; 
(ii)  improved training and results for financial institution statisticians and managers; 
(iii)  an information technology (IT) framework for rural financial institutions’ statistical 
data management as a knowledge product; and 
(iv)  support to the Irving Fisher Committee on Central Bank Statistics meeting in the 
PRC, where findings will be presented.5 
 
12.  To complete the outputs, the following steps are envisaged. Counties will be selected in 
pilot provinces on the basis of (i) the concentration of county-level rural financial institutions, (ii) the 
interest of rural financial institutions in participation, and (iii) observed weaknesses in statistical 
reporting  of  rural  financial  institutions.  After  consultant  recruitment  and  finalization  of  county 
selections, an international study tour of data collection systems for rural financial institutions will be 
conducted in selected countries. The PBC will undertake start-up workshops and assessments in 
selected counties to determine the level of data currently collected, how it is stored and used, and 
mechanisms  that  can  be  used  for  computerization.  The  computer  firm,  with  inputs  from  the 
consultants, will then design a template for data requirements aiming at statistical standardization 
and options for computerization methods; and estimate costs for institutions to convert electronic 
data. The TA consultants and PBC will work with target rural financial institutions to help complete 
their plans for conversion to electronic data submissions to the PBC. The draft results will be 
reviewed by a peer group composed of statisticians and computer software specialists and will be 
revised accordingly. The TA will then support interested rural financial institutions to computerize 
rural financial statistics reporting requirements and submit the rural credit statistics reports to the 
PBC by electronic means. After the initial work, the team will review and revise the process and 
refine the results. Based on the above activities, the TA will develop an IT framework for rural 
financial institutions’ statistical data management. The results will be published as a technical note. 
 
13.  To  achieve  the  training  results,  the  TA  will  initially  assess  and  conduct  a  pretest  to 
determine the level of knowledge of rural financial institution managers and statisticians on how 
they  access  and  use  data  to  develop  markets  and  serve  clients;  and  include  reviews  of 
computerization. The work will include a review of the training methodology that enables the 
participants to learn most effectively. The TA team will design a training course using the results of 
the electronic submission template and the knowledge of managers and statisticians. The team will 
deliver the training course and perform a posttest, analyzing the differences between the pretest

and posttest and revising the training course. Based on the findings of the course and testing, the 
TA will assist the PBC in establishing a training course into PBC training colleges as a knowledge 
product, replicate the training; and provide relevant training materials (including videos and printed 
materials) and use internet-based training. 
 
14.  Targeted workshops will be organized for different stakeholders at various stages of TA 
implementation.  These  will  include  but  not  be  limited  to  an  inception  workshop,  an  interim 
workshop, and a draft final report workshop. All workshops are expected to be attended by an ADB 
mission, government officials, consultants, and specialists in relevant fields to ensure the inclusion 
of diverse views and wide dissemination of project outputs. The PBC will ensure that all finalized 
reports and recommendations are circulated across all relevant local government departments and 
rural finance institutions.    
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $400,000 which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources).  The  government  will  provide 
counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office,  office  supplies,  domestic 
transportation, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2. The PBC has agreed to make other direct contributions in the following areas: 
all international study tour costs in excess of the TA budget; and all workshop costs in excess of 
the TA budget. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The TA will begin on 1 July 2012 and end on 31 December 2014 for a total of 30 months. 
The Statistics Department of the PBC will be the executing agency.  
17.  The TA will cover remuneration, travel, and per diem of consultants, as well as training, 
workshops,  and  miscellaneous  expenses.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  done  in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time).  
 
18.  There will be two individually recruited consultants; one international computer statistics 
specialist for 2 person-months, and a national credit market data specialist for 2 person-months. 
All consultants will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for consultants are in 
Appendix 3, with deliverables linked to the design and monitoring framework. All consultants’ 
reports will be prepared and provided in English and Chinese. The consultants will maintain 
close working relations with the PBC and will regularly discuss project progress and findings.  
 
19.  A  computer  software  development  firm  will  be  recruited  using  the  consultants 
qualification selection system. The firm will complete and demonstrate computerized systems of 
rural credit data reporting that meet PBC requirements and can be used by managers to 
improve performance. The scope of work involves familiarization with existing systems (manual 
and computerized) for data flows in small rural financial institutions, definition of a methodology 
for computerized data aggregation and reporting, assessment and recommendations for cost-
effective  computerization  of  reporting,  and  oversight  of  installation  and  use  in  three  rural 
financial institutions. The firm will work very closely with the PBC to achieve the results.

5 
20.  The PBC will supervise the day-to-day work of the consultants and take responsibility for 
administering national training programs, seminars, workshops, and international study visits. 
ADB will assist the PBC in overall TA operations, monitoring, facilitating international study tours, 
and disseminating knowledge results. 
 
21.  The project-specific indicators and targets in the design and monitoring framework will 
be  monitored  by  the  PBC  with  ADB  support.  Policy  dialogue  will  be  maintained  with  the 
government and project-specific issues will be discussed with government counterparts during 
review missions. Technical milestones will be monitored by reports to be prepared by the 
consultants  and  reviewed  by  the  PBC  and  project  officer.  The  team  leader  will  monitor 
milestones related to TA implementation. 
 
22.  The  knowledge  products  include  a  technical  note  with  the  methodology  and  an  IT 
framework for computerized submissions of rural credit statistics, a training program document, 
and a summary presentation of the results and implications. The knowledge products will be 
disseminated by the PBC training institutes, through the ADB and PBC websites, and at the 
proposed international seminar.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  Capacity  Building  on  Statistical 
Competence for County-Level Financial Institutions, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
1.  One international consultant (2 person-months), one software development firm, and 
one  national  consultant  (2  person-months)  will  be  selected  and  engaged  by  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The consultants will be individually engaged and the firm will be 
engaged using the consultants qualifications selection system. Consultants will be required to 
provide deliverables consistent with the design and monitoring framework activities, outputs, 
and delivery dates; reports are to be of high quality and produced in English, with copies in 
Chinese also produced by the report delivery dates. Precise work timelines and deliverables will 
be defined at inception and agreed with the People’s Bank of China (PBC) and ADB. 
 
A.  International Consultant Credit Systems Statistician (2 person-months) 
 
2.  Purpose, scope of work, and qualifications. The purpose of this assignment is for the 
consultant to facilitate the design and implementation of a system of computerized rural credit 
data  submission  and  analysis  to  the  PBC.  The  scope  involves  provision  of  experience  in 
computerization of statistics systems for small rural financial institutions, and suggestions for 
information technology (IT) templates. The expert will have suitable tertiary qualifications in 
economics and statistics, with at least 10 years’ experience working with credit statistics issues 
and computerization. The expert will be have strong English language writing and speaking 
skills,  and  have  worked  in  developing  countries  on  such  issues  with  financial  institutions, 
preferably with regulators. Experience in Asia, particularly in the People’s Republic of China 
(PRC), will be an advantage.  
 
3.  Tasks. The consultant will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  document best practices and options for conversion of small financial institutions’ 
statistics from manual to computerized systems;  
(ii)  manage team discussions, ongoing stakeholder dialogue, and construction of the 
final reports to help ensure international good practice is taken into account; 
(iii)  assess whether development of the automated reporting system complies with 
the new data reporting requirements and advise accordingly; 
(iv)  include consideration of the current types of hardware and software in use in 
rural financial institutions and the capacity of wireless and telephone systems to 
transmit data securely and rapidly; 
(v)  arrange and manage the meetings and schedule for the study tour to the most 
relevant location; and 
(vi)  perform quality control on the final English versions of all reports. 
 
B.  Financial Systems Software Development (Firm)    
 
4.  Purpose, scope of work, and qualifications. The purpose of this assignment is to 
complete and demonstrate computerized systems of rural credit data reporting that meet PBC 
requirements and are used by managers to improve performance. The scope of work involves 
familiarization with existing systems (manual and computerized) for data flows in small rural 
financial  institutions,  definition  of  a  methodology  for  computerized  data  aggregation  and 
reporting, assessment and recommendations for cost-effective computerization of reporting, and 
oversight  of  installation  and  use  in  three  rural  financial  institutions.  A  computer  software 
development firm will be recruited under the consultants qualifications selection system. The 
PBC will prepare more detailed terms of reference, advertise the assignment, and request for 
amplified  expressions  of  interest  and  information  on  the  consultant’s  experience  and

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
competence relevant to the assignment; after this, a shortlist of at least three firms will be 
established and the PBC will select the firm with the most relevant qualifications and references 
based on the expressions of interest. Only the first ranked firm will be asked to submit a 
combined technical and financial proposal and be invited to negotiate the contract, which ideally 
will be on a lump-sum basis. 
 
5.  Tasks. The software development firm will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  assess existing data reporting systems (manual and computerized) for small rural 
financial institutions, both hardware and software;  
(ii)  provide a technical and costs methodology for computerized data aggregation 
and reporting in accordance with new PBC requirements and institutional needs; 
provide information on ongoing maintenance costs and methods for the new 
systems; 
(iii)  oversee installation and use in three rural financial institutions; 
(iv)  complete research on business management for rural credit cooperatives in three 
provinces and develop an IT template for three levels of rural financial institutions; 
(v)  manage team discussions, ongoing stakeholder dialogue, and construction of the 
final reports to help ensure international good practice is taken into account; 
(vi)  ensure timely provision of key data collection outputs in accordance with the 
design and monitoring framework in high quality, inclusive of a national rollout 
plan for computerization; and   
(vii)  perform quality control on the final Chinese versions of all reports. 
 
C.  National Consultant: Credit Statistics Training Specialist (2 person-months) 
 
6.  Purpose, scope of work, and qualifications. The purpose of this work is to ensure 
successful design and use of the statistical system by financial institution staff and regulators. 
The  scope  of  work  involves  assessing  current  levels  of  understanding  and  use  of  data, 
designing and delivering training systems to upgrade the skills of regulators and rural financial 
institution managers (including pre- and post-testing of the participant’s knowledge to measure 
levels of learning from the training), and facilitating installation of the training programs into 
suitable  training  institutions.  The  consultant  should  possess  suitable  bachelor  or  master’s 
degree  qualifications  in  finance,  economics,  or  a  related  discipline;  and  at  least  10 years’ 
experience in the areas of training in rural financial institution growth and use of information and 
analysis. He or she must have good knowledge and sufficient experience in the area of rural 
financial market structure and operations of the PRC credit market. Extensive field experience 
and knowledge of the stakeholders and market weaknesses is important. The expert will have 
strong Chinese language speaking and writing skills; and must have good skills in English or 
may recruit and work with a translator for all meetings, conferences, and reports at his or her 
own cost.  
 
7.  Tasks. The consultant will perform the following tasks: 
 (i)  using focus groups and interviews in field studies, determine current levels of 
understanding and use of rural credit data collected by the PBC both inside and 
outside rural financial institutions as well as by PBC local offices; determine the 
level of computerization skills to use for analysis; and based on this, provide a 
training needs assessment with information on the training methodologies likely 
to be most effective with these groups;  
(ii)  design and deliver (a) pretests for both PBC officials and rural financial institution 
managers  and  supervisors,  (b)  training  systems  to  upgrade  the  skills  of

regulators  and  rural  financial  institution  managers,  and  (c)  testing  of  trainee 
knowledge after the training to determine understanding of information; 
(iii)  3 months after training, perform spot checks in the offices of training participants 
to see how they have incorporated their learning into their work, and provide 
support as needed;   
(iv)  with the PBC, facilitate installation of the training programs into suitable training 
institutions; and   
(v)  assist the team leader to prepare the inception, interim, and final reports.
